Having well considered the disgusting origin of flesh and the cruelty\nof fettering and slaying corporeal beings, let him entirely abstain from eating\nflesh.&nbsp; -<b>Manusmriti 5.48-49<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ashvam naa himseeh |</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A horse is not to be\nharmed - <b>Yajurveda. 13/42 -5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cFlesh cannot be had\nfrom grass or wood or stone. Unless a living creature is killed it cannot be\nprocured. Hence is the fault of eating flesh. The celestials who live upon\nSvaha, Svadha, and nectar, are given to truth and sincerity. Those persons,\nhowever, who are for satisfying the sensation of taste, should be known as\nRakshasas [flesh-eating demons] pervaded by the quality of Darkness. (<b>Mahabharata 115.24-25</b>) 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">gaam maa himseeraditim\nviraajam ||</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The cow is aditi. She\nis not to be harmed in any manner.&nbsp; -<b>Yajurveda. 13/43&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Breehimattam\nyavamattamatho maashamatho tilam,&nbsp;&nbsp; Esha\nvaam bhaago nihito ratnadheyaaya dantau maa hinsishtam pitaram maataram</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">O teeth! You eat rice,\nyou eat barley, you gram and you eat sesame. These cereals are specifically\nmeant for you. Do not kill those who are capable of being fathers and mothers. --<b>Atharvaveda 6.140.2<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anumantaa vishasitaa\nnihantaa krayavikrayee,&nbsp;&nbsp; Samskartaa\nchopahartaa cha khadakashcheti ghaatakaah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Those who permit\nslaying of animals; those who bring animals for slaughter; those who slaughter;\nthose who sell meat; those who purchase meat; those who prepare dish out of it;\nthose who serve that meat and those who eat are all murderers.- <b>Manusmrithi 5.51<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ya aamam maansamadanti\npaurusheyam cha ye kravih,&nbsp;&nbsp; Garbhaan\nkhaadanti keshavaastaanito naashayaamasi &nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We ought to destroy\nthose who eat cooked as well as uncooked meat, meat involving destruction of\nmales and females, foetus and eggs. <b>Atharvaveda\n8.6.23<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Meat can never be\nobtained without injury to living creatures, and injury to sentient beings is\ndetrimental to the attainment of heavenly bliss; let him therefore shun the use\nof meat. Having well considered the disgusting origin of flesh and the cruelty\nof fettering and slaying corporeal beings, let him entirely abstain from eating\nflesh.\u201d (<b>Manu-samhita 5.48-49)</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\u201cHe who purchases flesh, kills living\ncreatures through his money. He who eats flesh, kills living beings through his\neating. He who binds or seizes and actually kills living creatures is the\nslaughterer. These are the three sorts of slaughter through each of these acts.\nHe who does not himself eat flesh but approves of an act of slaughter, becomes\nstained with the sin of slaughter. <b>(Mahabharata\n115.38-39</b>) 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cThe sins generated by\nviolence curtail the life of the perpetrator. Therefore, even those who are\nanxious for their own welfare should abstain from meat-eating.\u201d (<b>Mahabharata, Anu.115.33</b>) 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When one\u2019s food is pure\n( devoid of meat ) , one\u2019s being becomes pure \u2013 </span><b style=\"font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ch\u0101ndogya Upani\u1e63ad 7.26.2</b></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">LISTEN, I AM NOT IN THE HABIT OF PROVIDING PROOFS &nbsp;- when CHOOTS ask me for proofs my usual answer is to them is \"FU#K OFF!\" &nbsp;- &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">I MAKE AN EXCEPTION IN THIS POST TO CONVINCE &nbsp;PM &nbsp;NARENDRA MODI .&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Vedic sacred Sanskrit\ntexts &nbsp;the cow is a symbol of the divine\nbounty of the earth and ALL the ancient scriptures prohibit the slaughter of\ncows. &nbsp;&nbsp;The slaughter of any animal goes\nagainst the principle of ahimsa.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The white invader imported Gandhi from South\nAfrica to secure Ahimsa for themselves , to save their own deceitful white asses .<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ahimsa is not causing\npain to any living being at any time through the actions of one's mind, speech\nor body.- &nbsp;&nbsp;<b>Sandilya Upanishad 5000 BC</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Maharishis saw life\nas the very stuff of the Divine, an emanation of the Source and part of a\ncosmic continuum. &nbsp;They held that each\nlife form, even water and trees, possesses consciousness and energy. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nonviolence,\nahimsa, the primary basis of vegetarianism, has long been central to the\nreligious traditions of India- especially Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism. &nbsp;Religion in India has consistently upheld the\nsanctity of life, whether human, animal or, in the case of the Jains,\nelemental.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word GAU ( cow )\nhas multiple meanings in the Vedas , it is a holy thing. It could be the humped\ncow, holy waters, llife giving sun rays , Vedic Sanskrit verses , holy rishis or\neven bountiful mother earth. Throughout the Vedas the cow is referred to as &nbsp;\"aghnya.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">AGHNYA &nbsp;means \"not to be killed or violated\"\nand is used for cows and for life sustaining waters in the presence of which\noaths were taken.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Rig and Sama Veda\ncall the cow \"aghnya\" and \"Aditi\", ie. not to be murdered\n(Rig 1-64-27; 5-83-8; 7-68-9; 1-164-40; 8-69-2; 9-1-9; 9-93-3; 10-6-11;\n10-87-16). They extol the cow as un-killable, un-murderable, whose milk\npurifies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">the mind and keeps it\nfree from sin. Verse 10-87-16 prescribes severe punishment for the person who\nkills a cow. &nbsp;The&nbsp; Atharva Veda recommends beheading (8-3-16)\nfor such a crime; the Rig Veda advocates expulsion from the&nbsp; kingdom (8-101-15).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of course Vedic\nliteratures are replete with stories of Kings who hunted animals regularly. &nbsp;This was maily to contain the menace of\nviolent animals. &nbsp;They did NOT kill\ncows.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This allowed the sages to meditate\npeacefully in the forest and write verses which would benefit &nbsp;the whole of human society. Secondly, it honed\nthe fighting skills and prowess of the ruling class. &nbsp;This enabled them to protect innocent citizens\nfrom enemies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanskrit dictionary\nVachaspatyam </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Panini created a special sutra to establish the rule\nthat goghn will only mean the receiver of a cow (andwill not be used in any\nother sense). </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pandit Taranath ignored\nPanini's injunction and wrote that \"goghn\" means \"the</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">killer of a cow.\" </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tarananth similarly converted the ashvamedh yagna\nfrom 'ritual of the horse' to the \"killing of the</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">horse.\"</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ashwamedham was a VOTE OF\nCONFIDENCE sought by an emperor ( for lasting peace ) so that he could send\nsoldiers back to their families .</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Max Muller made sure\nthat R rewarded Pundit Taranath with a kings ransom.&nbsp; In 1866, Lt. Governor Sir Cecil Beadon\nsanctioned ten thousand rupees for two hundred copies of his dictionary. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This was a fortune in those days,as the headmaster of a vernacular primary school received a salary of just 10 rupees a month. &nbsp;Today, &nbsp;those ten thousand rupees is the equivalent of 60 lakh rupees.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Babur in his letter of\n935 hijri advised Humayun to stop cow-slaughter. Akbar in his firman of 1586\nforbade cow slaughter. Aurangzeb did not eat meat. Akbar and Aurangzeb always\nused Ganga water for drinking and in their kitchen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In (XI.116) Manusmriti\nhas &nbsp;prescribed penance for killing a\ncow. In (XI.96) Manusmriti says that flesh is food of Pisachas &amp; Rakshasas.\n&nbsp;In (V.45 to 54), killing of animals and\neating of flesh has been prohibited in Manu Smriti. &nbsp;(V.54) says that totally avoiding eating flesh\nis a great reward (punya). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">How many Americans would eat a turkey at Thanksgiving if\nthey had to kill it themselves ?&nbsp;This year, 1.7 billion Muslims, or close to a\nquarter of the world population, celebrated Eid-al-Adha, the largest Islamic\nholiday of the year, with the \"sacrifice\" of 105 million cows, goats\nand sheep. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as Thanksgiving is often\ncalled Turkey Day, Eid-al-Adha is often called Bakra Eid, which translates to\nCow Feast or Goat Feast. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While Eid\nslaughter is often decried as barbaric, Thanksgiving slaughter isn't, even\nthough the only difference between the two is who wields the knife -- the\nconsumer or the worker. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Two very important\nfeatures for developing a psychological profile of an offender are his\nsignature and his modus operandi. The signature may be the way a rope is tied\naround a victim's hands or the particular way the victim is tortured. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Modus operandi (MO)\nrefers to the particular method of operation of the killer, including the\nobject of the crime, the means, the time, and so on. The MO can change, but the\nsignature usually doesn't.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every psychopath serial\nkiller leaves behind a SIGNATURE- it is a pathological need . Jack the Ripper,\nleft a gruesome signature-- the ripping of the bodies of his victims.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The signature aspect,\nor calling card, is the unique, personal expression or ritual demonstrated by\nthe offender while he is committing the offense and is based on the offender's\nfantasies. &nbsp;When a signature is left, so\nis an aspect of the offender's personality. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The signature aspect is\ndifferent from the modus operandi&nbsp; because\nit is conduct that goes beyond the necessary behaviors needed to commit the\ncrime. &nbsp;It is driven by the killer's\nfantasies and needs to be done in order for the killer to gain satisfaction\nfrom his crime. &nbsp;A modus operandi may\nevolve, but a signature aspect remains constant. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some psychopaths enjoy\ntaunting the police with letters describing their crimes and indicating where\nthey could find his most recent victim's body. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Serial murderers\nrepresent perhaps the most serious and morbidly fascinating image of\ncriminality. They're modern-day bogeymen. &nbsp;They commit horrific acts of violence and\nindulge in strange and perverted acts with their victims. , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wanna hear some\nBULLSH#T Gangamma stories created by the white invader over BRANDY AND CIGARS to\nmake Hindus look like monkeys ?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BULLSH#T &nbsp;STORY NUMBER ONE:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE:&nbsp; Gangamma is the incarnation of Shakti. &nbsp;It is at Diguvapalli, Chowdepalli(mandal),\nChittoor (District), near Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, her temple is dedicated to\nthe sister of Venkateswara. &nbsp;The temple\nis located 153 km from Bengaluru, 20 km from Madanapalli.&nbsp; &nbsp;Centuries ago the tribals Boyas and Yelikas\nlived in the forest area around the hillock. They stood up and resented the\nrepressive and automatic rule of the Nawabs. &nbsp;They retaliated against the Muslim soldiers\nand chased them. &nbsp;The Golconda Nawab\nrushed additional troops to crush the revolt. &nbsp;Boya tribals could not withstand the onslaught\nof the Muslim army and fled into the forest and prostrated near the hillock and\nprayed Almighty to save them. &nbsp;The spirit\nof the Goddess Shakti descended from the hillock, shielded the tribals and\ncrushed the Nawab's army. &nbsp;Local people\nsay that the Shakti has tied the heads of soldiers to banyan tree branches. In\nthe event of victory Boyas built the Gangamma temple, which saved them against\nevil force. The local goddess Gangamma is revered as the younger sister of Lord\nVenkateswara of Tirumala and hence the festival assumes enormous significance: UNQUOTE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BULSH#T STORY NUMBER\nTWO:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE : &nbsp;Sri Thathaya Gunta Gangamma is Grama Devatha\nof Tirupati town. Once upon a time when Tirupati and surrounding areas are\nruled by \u201cPalegondulu\u201d, harassment on women was enormous - they use to rape and\nharass any woman seen. During this time, in a village \u201cAvilala\u201d, the Goddess\nGangamma was born and grew into a most beautiful women. When the Palegondulu\nwant harm Goddess Gangamma, she with her grace and power tried to kill him.\nPalegondulu, fearing her, hid in a remote place. To take him out of hiding, the\nGangamma planned \u201cGanga Jathra\u201d where the people in Tirupathi do vichitra\nveshadarana and curse Gangamma for a period of 7 days. On the seventh day,\nthe\u201cPalegondulu\u201d comes out of hiding and is killed by Goddess Gangamma for the\n\u201cLokaKalyanam\u201d (well being of all people) :UNQUOTE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BULLSH#T STORY NUMBER THREE\n:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE:&nbsp; A Palegar (local chieftain) ruling the\nTirupati region, was known to sexually assault young women, while an angered\nAdiparashakti takes birth as Gangamma, taking a vow to slay him to protect\nwomen. The Palegar goes into hiding and Gangamma dons various guises to find\nhim out. To symbolize the legend, devotees even today visit the temple in\nvarious guises such as \u2018Banda Vesham\u2019, \u2018Bairagi Vesham\u2019, \u2018Thoti Vesham\u2019, \u2018Dora\nVesham\u2019, \u2018Mathangi\u2019, \u2018Sunnapu Kundalu\u2019, \u2018Perantala Vesham\u2019 and \u2018Sapparalu\u2019\nduring the nine-day event.&nbsp; Priests made\nthe traditional huge clay idol of the goddess at the temple's portico and later\nsmashed it into pieces at the auspicious moment. &nbsp;Devotees then clamour around to get the clay\nsmithereens, which they consider as sacred, to be either preserved in the\n\u2018Puja' room or consumed by mixing it in water.&nbsp;\nCows, goats and fowls are sacrificed at a corner of the temple. some\nwomen came draped with neem leaves, as a fulfilment of a vow ( giving a PEEK A\nBOO view of their private parts ): UNQUOTE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BULLSH#T STORY NUMBER FOUR\n:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE: &nbsp;&nbsp;The local chieftain \u201cPalegadu\u201d - athug - used\nto seduce beautiful women. &nbsp;As per his\ncommands, newly-wedwomen were forced to spend their first wedded night with\nhim. &nbsp;Thewomen prayed to Goddess\nJaganmatha who took birth as Gangamma, at Avilala village, near Tirupati. When\nshe grew up, the chieftain cast his lustful eyes on her. &nbsp;Palegadu insulted Gangamma, by pulling her\nhand in full public view when the latter rejected him. &nbsp;When She showed her frightening \u201cViswaroopam\u201d\nto him, to escape death, the chieftain fled. The age-old practice for devotees\nvisiting Tirupati is to first visit the Goddess before undertaking the trek up\nthe Tirumala hills. The annual \u2018Gangamma jatara' -- the festival celebrated by\nfisherwomen accompanied by their family members to offer prayers to the goddess\nof water to bless them with a safe and happy fishing season&nbsp; ( fishermen are roped in ). Fishing Boat\nOperators' Association president P.C. Appa Rao said the \u2018Gangamma jatara' was\nan annual ritual to seek the blessings of goddess Gangamma for good catch\nduring the new season and to ensure safe voyage : UNQUOTE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BULLSH#T STORY NUMBER FIVE\n:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE: &nbsp;&nbsp;One\nyear a guru by name Tirupati Tatacharya was passing by the village. He was the\nonly one available for the villagers at the time. But then he was a guru. They\nfound it impossible to kill a learned man as a sacrificial animal. &nbsp;Tatacharya found out about the moral dilemma\nfaced by the villagers. He told the villagers that he would meet the goddess on\nhis own and sort it out. The fateful day arrived. Tatacharya on his part asked\nall his disciples to assemble and continuously chant the famous and all\npowerful Ashtakshari mantra.&nbsp; He for\nhimself prepared two hot iron rods that had the conch and discus shapes on\ntheir edges. Conch and discus (Shanku and Chakra) are two holy symbols\nassociated with Lord Vishnu and his Vaishnavite devotees. As the jaatara was in\nprogress, the goddess appeared. As usual she took control of one of the\ndevotees and demanded that her food be presented in front of her.&nbsp; Tatacharya appeared in front of the goddess\nand took out the hot iron rods to plant the symbols on the goddess. The goddess,\ninitially tried to run away, but she failed in her attempts because of the\naffects of the Ashtakshari mantra being chanted by the disciples of Tatacharya.\nTatacharya tried to plant the symbols on shoulders but missed and planted the\nsymbols on the back instead, perhaps below the neck. The goddess submitted\nherself to Tatacharya and fell on his feet and sought his forgiveness.\nTatacharya accepted her as his disciple and moved her to Tirupati and\nestablished a temple for her on the outskirts of Tirupati. :&nbsp; UNQUOTE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">DURING THE JATARA THE\nPEOPLE SING SEXUALLY EXPLICIT SONGS AND SHOUT &nbsp;FILTHY &nbsp;SEXUAL\nSLANG..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--for 7 days and on the seventh and final day, when he heard people\nhurling abuses against the Goddess, the Palegondulu came out of his hiding hole\n. &nbsp;TEEE HEEEEEEE !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE : During the\nfestival period, devotees clad in various 'vesam' (disguise), criss-cross the\nstreets of the temple town shouting filthy words as part of the tradition to\ndrive away evil forces and offer prayers to different folk goddess in the\ntemples. Smearing sandalwood paste all over the body, the devotees wear\nglittering clothes and cover their heads with jasmine garlands. To smoke the\nbad sexual predator him out of his hideout the&nbsp;\npeople in Tirupathi do vichitra veshadarana and curse Gangamma USING\nFOUL LANGUAGE for a period of 7 days. On the seventh day the \u201cPalegondulu\u201d comes\nout of the hide and is killed by Godess Gangamma for the \u201cLokaKalyanam\u201d. The\nmales, children and youth, traverse the streets dancing and singing lewd songs\nand hurling abuses at others and at her. You can spot scores of males dressed\nup as women daintily walking down the streets alone, in groups or in procession\nwith drums and band, and visiting her in her twin temples. He\nwanted his disciples to bear this burden . The proud Yagna Valkya told his\nguru, that he himself can do the needful easily , and hence why involve his\ndisciples ?<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Vaishampayana got very\nangry at these words . To add insult to injury Yagnavalkya offered to do the\nperform the penalty all by himself and he could spare all the pupils and the\nguru from dissolving the dosha burden.&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">This made the guru even more angry as\nthis he construed as supreme arrogance and a posture unbecoming of a disciple.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Vaisampayana ordered\nYajnavalkya to give back all the Vedic learning and wisdom that he acquired\nfrom him dismissed him from his gurukul.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">leave his school\nimmediately. Yajnavalkya followed the orders of the professor and discarded all\nthe learning, which immediately evaporated into the solar dimension. And he\nbecame poorer in his knowledge and hence in powers and luster.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Yajnavalkya\nfollowed the orders of the maharishi and mentally discarded all the learning,\nwhich immediately evaporated into the akasha And he immediately became poorer\nin his knowledge and hence in powers. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The guru could see his\npupils aura shrink instantly as he absorbed all the aura into his own . So our\nman Yajnavalkya underwent this process at midday and became ignorant\u2014 USKA\nBAARAH BAJ GAYA !.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">He prayed to Goddess\nSaraswathi .<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Yajnavalkya approached\nthe Sun God and implored him to teach him more than what he lost and more than\nwhat a human like his Guru knew. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The Sun God agreed to\nteach and asked him to follow him in the form a horse during his continuous\ntravel across the skies and learn. Yagna Valkya had to face the sun god\u2019s\nchariot and traverse in reverse with the same speed . <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Thus Yajnavlakya became\na Vajasaneya, one who learned as a horse and a branch formed called Vajasaneya\nsakha. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">This Yajurveda learned\nby Yajnavlkya as a horse from the Sun God is called SuklaYajurveda and the\nearlier one that was learned from Vaismpayana was Krishna Yajurveda. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">THIS FAKE STORY IS\nPOISON INJECTED BY THE WHITE INVADER , AS LORD VISHNU HAD NOT YET ASSUNED HIS\nKRISHNA AVATAR .<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">They have injected\npoison in many ways -- when Yajnavalkya vomited out his knowledge , other\ndisciples ate the vomit like absorbed it like Tittiri birds and hence the\nbranch that came from those disciples is called Tittiriya sakha. .&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The white\nhistorian wrote that Adi shankaracharya ( actually born 4000 years ago\u2014but\nkicked forward in time by 2800 years ) followed the Taittiriya Shakha.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">ALL BULL..<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The Yajurveda has been\nsplit into white and black and the shattered into splinters again \u2013 and\ndifferent parts of India follow different systems\u2014all part of a GRAND DIVIDE\nAND RULE.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">For example the Krishna\n( black ) Yajurveda has many parts followed by various parts of India. The FAKE\nmutts have assisted in this.<o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Example?- There are\nfour recensions of the Krishna Yajurveda:<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Taittiriya sa\u1e43hita--\noriginally of Panchala<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Maitrayani sa\u1e43hita-\noriginally of the area south of Kurukshetra<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Caraka-Ka\u1e6dha sa\u1e43hita --\noriginally of Madra and Kurukshetra<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kapi\u1e63\u1e6dhala-Ka\u1e6dha sa\u1e43hita--\nof the southern Punjab and Bahika<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The white invader gave\nbull that Lord Rama\u2019s clan follows the Shukla Yajurveda branch\u2014to DRIVE A WEDGE\nbetween Krishna/ Rama followers..<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The Vajasaneyi Samhita\n( Shulka Yajurveda \u2013white ) has forty chapters or adhyayas, containing the\nformulas used with the following rituals:<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">1.-2.: New and Full\nMoon sacrifices<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">3.: Agnihotra<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">4.-8.: Somayajna<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">9.-10.: Vajapeya and\nRajasuya, two modifications of the Soma sacrifice<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">11.-18.: construction\nof altars and hearths, especially the Agnicayana<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">19.-21.: Sautramani, a\nritual originally counteracting the effects of excessive Soma-drinking<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">22.-25.: Ashvamedha (\npoison injected with queens having sex with a dead horse\u2019s phallus ) <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">26.-29.: supplementary\nformulas for various rituals<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">30.-31.: Purushamedha<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">32.-34.: Sarvamedha<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">35.: Pitriyajna<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">36.-39.: Pravargya<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">40.: the final adhyaya\nis the famous Isha Upanishad.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The Shukla Yajurveda\nhas two branches: Vajasaneyi Madhyandiniya &amp; Vajasaneyi Kanva. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Vajasaneyi\nMadhyandiniya is originally of Mithila and Vajasaneyi Kanva is of originally\nKosala.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Sri Shukla Yajur Veda\noriginally had 15 Sakhas out of which only two Sakhas or branches, called\nMadyandina and Kanva Sakhas are available at present .&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The Vedic rituals of the\nRanganathaswamy Temple at Srirangam, the second biggest temple in India, are\nperformed according to the Kanva shakha ( Shulka ) . <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Madyandina Saha was\nused by the north India fake mutts while Kanva Sakha is used in South India\u2019s\nFAKE mutts. Today even Zakir Naik quotes from Yajur Veda to ridicule Hindus.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Adi Shankaracharya had\ntaken the original YAJUR VEDA from the Kerala namboodiris and deposited it in\nthe librarby of the original Sringeri Mutt 4000 years ago--.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The North India ( white\n) versus South India ( black ) divide by an immoral DIVIDE introduced by the\nwhite invader.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">They even made\nYagnavalkya , an avatar of Vishnu.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">So what are the\nsplinter groups?<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Madhyandina Yajurveda:\nfor North India- Pakistan, Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, Punjab, Bihar, Madhya\nPradesh, Rajasthan, Gujarat , Maharashtra ,, West Bengal, Assam, Nepal. This\nbranch includes Madhyandina Samhita, Madhyandina Shatapatha Brahmana, Ishavasya\nUpanishad and Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kanva Yajurveda: for\nNepal, HP, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, and Andhra Pradesh. Orissa party has a\ndifferent text.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Charaka Yajurveda: for\nMaharashtra, adjacent parts of Madhya Pradesh, Assam, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh.\nThey now follow Maitrayani YV shakha, as the white invader took texts away .<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Maitrayani Yajurveda:\nfor Gujarat, Maharashtra and Rajasthan<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kathaka Yajurveda:\nKashmir, Punjab and HP<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Charayaniya Katha\nYajurveda: for Kashmir.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kapisthala Katha\nYajurveda: for Punjab and, Gujarat. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Jabala Yajurveda:\nMaharashra and Gujarat<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Taittiriya Yajurveda:\nSouth India . The Taittiriyas are splintered into numerous sub-schools.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Baudhayana and Apastamba were found all over South India , Hiranyakeshins in\nKonkan and Western Maharashtra. The Vaikhanasas around Tirupati and Chennai.\nThe Vadhulas in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. The Agniveshyas, in Kerala and Tamil\nNadu<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; These IDIOTS perform Sandhya\nVandana at noon.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Shukla Yajurveda is\nalso known as Vajasaneya Yajurveda, because it was evolved in great rapidity by\nSun who was in the form of a horse through his manes .The rhythm of recital of\nthese vedas is set to the rhythm of the horse gallop .&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">In Sanskrit, term \"Vaji\"\nmeans horse. Yajnavalkya divided s Vajasaneya Yajurveda again into fifteen\nbranches, each branch comprising hundreds of Yajus Mantras. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">According to the\nMahabhasya of Patanjali, there were 21 shakhas of Rigveda, 9 of Atharvaveda,\n101 of Yajurveda , and 1000 varieties of chanting of Samaveda.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Only 20 or so\nShakhas of the Vedas are extant now, we do possess names of most of the lost\nShakhas of the Rigveda, Yajurveda and Atharvaveda. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Fragments of many of\nthe lost shakhas are also available as quotations in ancient works. font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pray?&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prithee ?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>TEEE HEEEEE !!!</b></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Swami Vivekananda gave in to the white man and announced in writing that ancient Hindus used to eat meat.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He wrote:-</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">\"You will be\nastonished if I tell you that, according to the old ceremonials, he is not a\ngood Hindu who does not eat beef. On certain occasions he must sacrifice a bull\nand eat it.\"</span></i> &nbsp;<b>&nbsp;-</b></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>The complete works of\nSwami Vivekananda, Volume 3, Pg 536&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Capt Ajit Vadakayil tells this &nbsp; - When Swami Vivekananda did NOT understand Hinduism, or when he could NOT even translate the Nasadiya Sukta of Rig Veda properly - what do you expect ?&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\">I leave it here &nbsp;-- we need some Hindu heroes , right ? &nbsp;See I am forced to tell &nbsp;this .
